data.title: Minnesota Timberwolves’ Al Jefferson reaching for national stardom
data.meta_description: Last season was a coming-out party for the Timberwolves’ Al Jefferson, who in 82 games went from a relative NBA unknown to a rising young star. On the national radar from the start this time, he’s looking at a possible breakout season, with the accolades and all-star recognition that go with it.Wolves owner Glen Taylor […]
data.text:
To place an obituary, please include the information from the obituary checklist below in an email to obits@pioneerpress.com. There is no option to place them through our website. Feel free to contact our obituary desk at 651-228-5263 with any questions.

General Information:

Your full name,

Address (City, State, Zip Code),

Phone number,

And an alternate phone number (if any)

Obituary Specification:

Name of Deceased,

Obituary Text,

A photo in a JPEG or PDF file is preferable, TIF and other files are accepted, we will contact you if there are any issues with the photo.

Ad Run dates

There is a discount for running more than one day, but this must be scheduled on the first run date to apply.

If a photo is used, it must be used for both days for the discount to apply, contact us for more information.

Policies:

Verification of Death:

In order to publish obituaries a name and phone number of funeral home/cremation society is required. We must contact the funeral home/cremation society handling the arrangements during their business hours to verify the death. If the body of the deceased has been donated to the University of Minnesota Anatomy Bequest Program, or a similar program, their phone number is required for verification.

Please allow enough time to contact them especially during their limited weekend hours.

A death certificate is also acceptable for this purpose but only one of these two options are necessary.

Guestbook and Outside Websites:

We are not allowed to reference other media sources with a guestbook or an obituary placed elsewhere when placing an obituary in print and online. We may place a website for a funeral home or a family email for contact instead; contact us with any questions regarding this matter.

Obituary Process:

Once your submission is completed, we will fax or email a proof for review prior to publication in the newspaper. This proof includes price and days the notice is scheduled to appear.

Please review the proof carefully. We must be notified of errors or changes before the notice appears in the Pioneer Press based on each day’s deadlines.

After publication, we will not be responsible for errors that may occur after final proofing.

Online:

All obituaries appear on TwinCities.com with a permanent online guestbook presence. If you wish to have the online presence removed, you can contact us to remove the guestbook online. Changes to an online obituary can be handled through the obituary desk. Call us with further questions.

Payment Procedure:

Pre-payment is required for all obituary notices prior to publication by the deadline specified below in our deadline schedule. Please call 651-228-5263 with your payment information after you have received the proof and approved its contents.

Credit Card: Payment accepted by phone only due to PCI (Payment Card Industry) regulations

EFT: Check by phone. Please provide your routing number and account number.

Cash: Accepted at our FRONT COUNTER Monday – Friday from 8:00AM – 3:30PM

Rates:

The minimum charge is $162 for the first 10 lines.

Every line after the first 10 is $12.20.

If the ad is under 10 lines it will be charged the minimum rate of $162.

On a second run date, the lines are $8.20 per line, starting w/ the first line.

For example: if first run date was 20 lines the cost would be $164.

Each photo published is $125 per day.

For example: 2 photos in the paper on 2 days would be 4 photo charges at $500.

Deadlines:

Please follow deadline times to ensure your obituary is published on the day requested.

Hours

Deadline (no exceptions)

Ad

Photos

MEMORIAM (NON-OBITUARY) REQUEST

Unlike an obituary, Memoriam submissions are remembrances of a loved one who has passed. The rates for a memoriam differ from obituaries.

Please call or email us for more memoriam information

Please call 651-228-5280 for more information.

HOURS: Monday – Friday 8:00AM – 5:00PM (CLOSED WEEKENDS and HOLIDAYS)

Please submit your memoriam ad to memoriams@pioneerpress.com or call 651-228-5280.

Last season was a coming-out party for the Timberwolves’ Al Jefferson, who in 82 games went from a relative NBA unknown to a rising young star.

On the national radar from the start this time, he’s looking at a possible breakout season, with the accolades and all-star recognition that go with it.

Wolves owner Glen Taylor is among those looking for big things from his big man, starting tonight in the season opener against Sacramento.

“Al Jefferson is not only a young star in this league,” Taylor said, “but as good as he is, he’ll probably improve and he’s certainly a guy you can build a franchise around.”

The Wolves are trying to do just that. Jefferson remains the team’s franchise player and brightest star.

Not that making the All-Star Game is his ultimate goal.

“I don’t even think about it,” he said. “With the All-Star Game, you never know what you’re going to get. Last year I had the numbers, but I didn’t have the wins. My only goal this year is to try to get better. Get better and better as a player and as a team and make the playoffs. I feel if we take care of that, the All-Star Game will come along.”

Forward Ryan Gomes, who came to Minnesota with Jefferson in the July 2007 trade that sent Kevin Garnett to Boston, is taking his teammate at his word.

With a little help from his friends, though, Gomes has no doubt this can be an all-star season for Jefferson.

“I think that’s what’s going to happen,” Gomes said. “We have to be there to have his back, too. He’s going to put up his numbers, get his 20 (points) and 10 (rebounds), and we have to be able to add to that. He’s our teammate, and we have to have his back every night. If we’re there at the end, we’re all going to get credit.”

To the Wolves’ credit, they moved to ease Jefferson’s burden during the offseason, acquiring rookie forward Kevin Love and guard/forward Mike Miller in a draft-night trade with Memphis.

With Miller and guards Randy Foye and Rashad McCants, the Wolves have three players who shot better than 40 percent from three-point range last season, so teams will have to think twice before ganging up on Jefferson in the low post this season.

“Most definitely, if the other team is smart,” Jefferson said. “I’m pretty sure I’m going to see double teams instead of triple teams this year.”

Before coming to the Wolves, Jefferson said he rarely drew any double teams and certainly not on a nightly basis.

Last season, that’s all he saw, at least after the first couple of months.

“Probably from the midway point on,” coach Randy Wittman said. “And he got it from everybody. It wasn’t like one team did it and another didn’t. They did it all the time.”

Jefferson said the constant double-teaming was frustrating at first but that he learned to adjust.

Wittman said that’s an area where Jefferson must continue to grow but that he’s way ahead of where he was a year ago.

“He’s playing with more confidence because he’s been through a year,” Wittman said. “I think the thing that’s going to stand out with Al is what steps he makes from a defensive standpoint. That’s the next step in his game that he has to improve on.”

When it comes to the rest of Jefferson’s game, there’s little room for improvement.

Coming off a season in which he posted career highs in scoring (21 points per game) and rebounds (11.1), Jefferson was limited during training camp by a sprained knee ligament, but it and he got better as the exhibition season went on.

Jefferson followed an opening 18-point, nine-rebound game at Milwaukee with seven more solid outings and finished exhibition play as the team leader in points (14.9) and rebounds (9.0) while playing a little more than 26 minutes per night.

The rest of the Wolves weren’t as consistent, but Jefferson feels good about the team and has high hopes.

“We’re young, but this is my fifth year coming up,” he said. “It’s Gomes’ fourth year. We’re young, but we’ve got some years in the league. Even though we’re young, we think this could be the first of many good years for us.”

Because this is a young team, Jefferson said it’s important to get off to a good start.

A 6-2 exhibition record is nothing to get too excited about, but it’s an encouraging first step for a team that lost 24 of its first 27 games last season on its way to a 22-60 finish.

“November and December are going to be big for us,” Jefferson said. “We’ve got to win games in those first two months. Once we do that, that will give us our confidence, but we can’t get relaxed then. We’ve got to keep it going.”

Originally Published: October 28, 2008 at 11:01 p.m.
